docs.snippet: Most home cooks need only one heavy Dutch oven, and one usually lasts a lifetime. Mine -- more than 50 years old -- belonged to my mother. But I am sorely tempted to buy one by Staub, a French brand adored by top chefs and now available in America...
docs.lead_paragraph: Most home cooks need only one heavy Dutch oven, and one usually lasts a lifetime. Mine -- more than 50 years old -- belonged to my mother. But I am sorely tempted to buy one by Staub, a French brand adored by top chefs and now available in America. These casseroles ''conduct heat beautifully, and yet they're elegant enough to go into the dining room,'' said David Waltuck of Chanterelle, which uses them (left). The black matte finish gives the pots a cast-iron look, but heavy enamel actually covers the cast iron. The pots are rustproof and need no seasoning. The lids have brass knobs, and studs on the underside encourage cooking juices to condense onto the surface of the food, automatically basting it. The pots range from one cup to 12 1/2 quarts. Sur La Table in Manhasset, N.Y., and around the country sells the cookware, which is $29.95 for the one-cup version to $235.95 for an eight-quart size. It can be ordered from (800) 243-0852, www.surlatable.com or from Staub, which carries the entire line and whose prices are slightly lower. Green, blue, yellow and purple casseroles are available from Staub, (866) 782-8287 and can be special-ordered from Sur La Table.

headline.main: A Dutch Oven From France Turns a Home Into a Hearth

docs.snippet: Blowfish tails are often sold under the names sea squab or chicken of the sea, though the odd-looking delicacies have nothing to do with birds. This has been a good season for blowfish, found off Long Island's south shore and the north New Jersey ...
docs.abstract: Comment on blowfish tails; some retail outlets listed; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Blowfish tails are often sold under the names sea squab or chicken of the sea, though the odd-looking delicacies have nothing to do with birds. This has been a good season for blowfish, found off Long Island's south shore and the north New Jersey coast. The tails are delicious morsels, with a single slender bone running their length. But few markets in Manhattan sell them because, the owners say, few people buy them and many do not even know what they are. I cook them like jumbo shrimp, dusting them with flour before sautéing in butter and garlic, or I briefly sear the tails on the grill. Sometimes I add them to paella or bouillabaisse. There are about 20 to a pound, and they cost $6 to $8 a pound. In Manhattan, they are often carried by Pescatore Seafood in the Grand Central Market, Catalano Fish in Eli's Manhattan and the Vinegar Factory; Rosedale; and Pisacane. In Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, look for the tails at Henry's Fish Market. But they are not available every day, so it pays to check.

headline.main: A Recipe for a Fish That Is Not A Household Name

docs.snippet: The season for fresh matjes herring is here, and Marcus Samuelsson, the chef at Aquavit, is making sushi with it. And you can, too. Cook a cup of short-grain Japanese white rice, then season it with one-fourth cup rice vinegar warmed with one tabl...
docs.abstract: Fresh matjes herring can be used to make sushi; recipe; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The season for fresh matjes herring is here, and Marcus Samuelsson, the chef at Aquavit, is making sushi with it. And you can, too. Cook a cup of short-grain Japanese white rice, then season it with one-fourth cup rice vinegar warmed with one tablespoon mirin and two tablespoons sugar. Form ovals of the rice, dab on some wasabi and top with a slice of herring. Or spread the rice on nori on a sushi mat, smear with a little wasabi or mustard, add pieces of the herring, roll it up and slice it into sushi rolls. Sometimes Mr. Samuelsson uses mashed potatoes seasoned with wasabi instead of rice.

headline.main: If the Vikings Had Discovered Sushi

docs.snippet: The increasing demand from restaurants and shops for stylish, artisanal breads and pastries has lead to the establishment of the Artisan Baking Center, a school at 36-46 37th Street in Long Island City, Queens. The center, which teaches experience...
docs.abstract: Artisan Baking Center, school in Long Island City, Queens, teaches experienced bakers how to cook stylish, artisanal breads and pastries that restaurants and bakeries are demanding lately; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The increasing demand from restaurants and shops for stylish, artisanal breads and pastries has lead to the establishment of the Artisan Baking Center, a school at 36-46 37th Street in Long Island City, Queens. The center, which teaches experienced bakers and those seeking jobs to work on the artisanal level, just completed a two-year pilot program and is now fully operating. Tuition is free. The center is supported by baking companies and union groups, including the Consortium for Worker Education. There is a job placement program and English-language training.

headline.main: Bread: It's Not Just a Loaf Anymore

docs.snippet: Spring begins today, so it is time for Andrew Shotts's new line of chocolates in salted caramel, mint tea and grapefruit, among other flavors. Mr. Shotts, above, a confectioner and pastry chef, makes his chocolates, Garrison Confections, at the Ch...
docs.abstract: Comment on Andrew Shott's new line of chocolates; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Spring begins today, so it is time for Andrew Shotts's new line of chocolates in salted caramel, mint tea and grapefruit, among other flavors. Mr. Shotts, above, a confectioner and pastry chef, makes his chocolates, Garrison Confections, at the Chocolate Loft, 119 West 23rd Street, which he owns with Guittard, a company in Burlingame, Calif., that makes chocolate mostly for professional use. Mr. Shotts's smallish, richly flavored pieces change every season. They are $12 for 10 pieces, and can be ordered from www.thechocolateloft.com, or by appointment at the loft. Mr. Shotts holds classes, most of the time for chefs, in candy making and pastry at the loft, which is also available to rent for parties and classes. For information: (212) 929-2545.

headline.main: New Chocolates Pop Up, Like Crocuses in Spring

docs.snippet: This potholder, channel-quilted like the sections of a piece of matzo, could qualify as Passover Pop Art if it weren't so useful. It's $4.95 at Broadway Panhandler, 477 Broome Street (Wooster Street). The store also sells a matzo mitt, $6.95, perf...
docs.abstract: Comment on potholder shaped like matzo; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: This potholder, channel-quilted like the sections of a piece of matzo, could qualify as Passover Pop Art if it weren't so useful. It's $4.95 at Broadway Panhandler, 477 Broome Street (Wooster Street). The store also sells a matzo mitt, $6.95, perfect for taking the roast chicken and tsimmes out of the oven.

headline.main: A Matzo Different From All Other Matzos

docs.snippet: Pierre Hermé, probably the premier pastry chef in France, is opening his own pastry and chocolate boutiques in Paris at a good clip. Mr. Hermé, above, who spent years working at Fauchon and Ladurée, the city's high-end fancy food and pastry pla...
docs.lead_paragraph: Pierre Hermé, probably the premier pastry chef in France, is opening his own pastry and chocolate boutiques in Paris at a good clip. Mr. Hermé, above, who spent years working at Fauchon and Ladurée, the city's high-end fancy food and pastry places, opened his first shop in August at 72, rue Bonaparte, on the Left Bank. About two weeks ago he opened a pastry counter in the Korova restaurant, 33, rue Marbeuf, in a fashionable Right Bank neighborhood, and a third shop is scheduled to open in May at 185, rue de Vaugirard, not far from the Eiffel Tower and where he has a big kitchen. His first store, narrow and chocolate-colored, has a glass-topped counter running its length that is filled with dazzling pastries lavished with cream, robed in chocolate and bejeweled with berries. Cases of chocolates and baskets of croissants are tucked into a wall opposite the counter. Kitchens for finishing pastries and dipping chocolates are on several levels beneath the shop.

headline.main: A Delightful Taste of Paris, by Way of Rochester

docs.snippet: I held my grandmother's hand as the plane took off from New York. ''Your hands are cold!'' she said. ''These hands are made for pastry. Don't you like to fly? You must not. I do. I think it's fun!''     ''Grandmom,'' I said, ''you may be the only ...
docs.abstract: Amanda Hesser article on dining out in Rome with her grandmother; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: I held my grandmother's hand as the plane took off from New York. ''Your hands are cold!'' she said. ''These hands are made for pastry. Don't you like to fly? You must not. I do. I think it's fun!'' ''Grandmom,'' I said, ''you may be the only person in America who feels that way right now.''

docs.snippet: Coffee lovers who insist on sipping espresso from a china cup should elbow up to the bar at Crestanello Gran Caffè Italiano, which just opened at 475 Fifth Avenue (41st Street). This sleek coffee shop and wine bar is the new American outpost for ...
docs.abstract: Crestanello Gran Caffe Italiano, sleek coffee shop and wine bar, opens at Fifth Avenue and 41st Street, Manhattan; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Coffee lovers who insist on sipping espresso from a china cup should elbow up to the bar at Crestanello Gran Caffè Italiano, which just opened at 475 Fifth Avenue (41st Street). This sleek coffee shop and wine bar is the new American outpost for Antonio Crestanello, who opened his first cafe, in Vicenza, near Venice, nearly two years ago. Pastry includes big, lush bomboloni and other desserts ($1.95 and to $3.75 a portion; $23 to $28 for a whole cake) made just for the shop by Goupil & DeCarlo, a fine East Village bakery. There are also panini, salads, cold plates, crepes and pastas ($5 to $13). Coffee drinks include a shakerati, an espresso shaken with ice and served in a martini glass. Tables are on two levels, with waiter service on the balcony. Hours: 7 a.m. to 9 p.m. weekdays, 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. weekends. The menu is available to go: the only time paper cups are used.

headline.main: Espresso in China Cups, Even in Martini Glasses

docs.snippet: Ron Kipps has raised bison in West Clifford, Pa., since 1985, but he has sold its meat in the Union Square Greenmarket for only the last few months. Shoppers on Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays will find his Elk Trails Bison Ranch truck parked th...
docs.abstract: Ron Kipps sells bison meat at Union Square Greenmarket; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Ron Kipps has raised bison in West Clifford, Pa., since 1985, but he has sold its meat in the Union Square Greenmarket for only the last few months. Shoppers on Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays will find his Elk Trails Bison Ranch truck parked there with cuts of meat and prepared products. Everything is sold frozen. Mr. Kipps said his method of freezing lets the meat remain fresh in the refrigerator for more than a week after it is thawed. It is extremely lean, so steaks are best cooked no more than medium-rare; all the cuts are on the chewy side except for tenderloin ($20 a pound). Garlic sausage ($7 a pound) and meatballs ($6.50 a pound) are superb, and hamburger patties ($5.50 a pound) are convenient to have in the freezer. Smoked slices ($10 a pound), which suggest corned beef, are ready to eat.

headline.main: The Bison Trail Leads to the Greenmarket
